He was quick to note that it was no self-congratulation of his beloved homeland, at least not entirely. âThe problem is, why do we get into so much trouble in the first place?â Looking at Portugal today, the reader would be forgiven for attributing Francaâs question to the humility of this gentle corner of Western Europe. Emerging from the 2008 global financial crisis, Portugal has engineered higher growth, lower inequality, increased employment, and decreased budget deficit, all the while defying austerity mandates from Brussels. Not that Brussels seemed to mind. Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission, publicly praised Portugalâs âbeautiful economic progressâ in March during a parliamentary meeting with Portuguese Prime Minister AntÃ³nio Costa.Â  But Franca, founder of analog semiconductor design firm Chipidea, is no casual observer of Portugalâs national development. âMuch of the buzz we hear these days about Portugalâs bourgeoning tech scene is, of course, wonderful, but we run the risk of believing our own hype and not doing enough to ensure early progress takes root and sprouts future progress.â Case in point: Web Summit, deemed âthe best tech conference on the planetâ by Forbes Magazine and coined âDavos for geeksâ by Bloomberg, moved to Lisbon two years ago and has drawn such A-list speakers as Jean Liu of Chinese ride-share and autonomous driving technology company Didi, Brian Krzanich of Intel, and the late Professor Stephen Hawking of Cambridge University, along with prominent venture capitalists and tech media moguls. Yet there seems to have been little subsequent foreign direct investment in research and development into Portugal. Without such investments, the thousands of engineering students that graduate each year from Portugalâs top universities must still find work abroad. But more important than talent drain, the absence of a strong engineering base means that a country would remain stuck as a net user  of technology rather than producer . It means that the country would be absent at the table where future technology standards are set, supply chains shaped, and long-lasting structural advantages concretized. Indeed, much of world history proves that, over the long run, not only are producer nations principal drivers of economic growth, they also reap most of the rewards.
